title: 113_hr2027
content: The Act titled "Expanding Patients' Access to Quality Care Act of 2013" includes modifications to Stark requirements for hospitals under construction or development as of December 30, 2010, and additional exceptions for physician ownership in hospitals facing financial distress. Section 1877(i) of the Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for hospitals under construction or development as of December 31, 2010, regarding their provider agreements and licensed capacities. The amendment to Section 1877(i) of the Social Security Act includes provisions for hospitals under construction or development as of December 31, 2010, regarding their provider agreements and licensed capacities. "A hospital is considered 'under development' on December 31, 2010, if it has submitted a Medicare provider agreement application, has a binding agreement for construction, and has spent at least 10% of the project cost or $1,000,000, or has obtained a certificate of need in a required State." SEC. 3. MODIFYING STARK REQUIREMENTS FOR APPLICABLE HOSPITALS TO QUALIFY FOR EXPANSION OF FACILITY CAPACITY. Section 1877(i)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to limit the frequency of increases in hospitals' capacity expansion. The Social Security Act is amended to limit hospital capacity expansion increases. This includes restrictions on previous increases and the Secretary's permission for further increases. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL EXCEPTION FOR PHYSICIAN OWNERSHIP AND INVESTMENT FOR HOSPITALS IN FINANCIAL DISTRESS. Section 1877(i) of the Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for hospitals in financial distress regarding physician ownership and investment. The amendment to Section 1877(i) of the Social Security Act includes provisions for hospitals in financial distress, defining it as having a negative operating margin for three consecutive cost reporting periods. The amendment defines financial distress for hospitals as having a negative operating margin for three consecutive cost reporting periods, and once identified as such, the hospital will be treated as in financial distress for all subsequent periods regardless of changes in operating margin.
